summary: A life-shattering secret torments Ben Thomas (Will Smith). In order to find redemption, he sets out to change the lives of seven strangers. Over the course of his journey, he meets and falls in love with a cardiac patient named Emily (Rosario Dawson), and in so doing, complicates his mission.

reviews.content: Could've been so much better. Although I do like the approach on how the story was told, it was riddled with sloppy filmmaking. It had way too many plot holes that could've easily been avoided with a tighter screenplay and/or better directing. All casting and performances were great, although Smith was awkward in some scenes - not the ones he was supposed to be awkward in. The cinematography and score was spot on, and the 123 min runtime flew by with the decent pacing. I'm not sure why the critics were so hard on this film, it's a unique story told in about the best way it could've been told without becoming overly predictable. It's too bad it fell short of being a great film with all the rookie filmmaking mistakes. Nevertheless, it's a well deserving 7/10 from me.

Will Smith makes up for his recent unsatisfying blockbusters 'I Am Legend' and 'Hancock' with this touching weeper. In an Oscar-caliber performance of charisma, guilt, and redemption, he delivers his best performance and his best film since 'The Pursuit of Happyness.' Smith re-teams with the Italian director of that film, Gabriele Muccino, to deliver this gripping and enigmatically-titled drama. It's a weeper, a cryptic mystery, and a winning romance with a righteous message. Smith has a terrific supporting cast in Barry Pepper, Woody Harrelson, Michael Ealy, and Rosario Dawson. Dawson, in particular, is simply outstanding. She all but steals the movie from Smith, and is the one who carries us emotionally through the film. It's not perfect--Muccino and the script lay on the sentiment a bit too much at times--but this is one tear-jerker that genuinely earns those tears

Despite a powerful performance from Will Smith, "Seven Pounds" is a grim, depressing and overly sentimental drama that doesn't work. Gabrielle Muccino's tear-jearker hasn't aged well since it was released in 2007. It's an intriguing premise for a movie that is poorly executed. Packed with morose sequences, corny dialogue and a bizarre ending, it offers a prime example of how not to make a melodrama. To be fair, though, the film does have a few merits that are worth mentioning. Will Smith is as always excellent and delivers one of his most moving performances in the lead role. With riveting expressions, he puts viewers into the mindset of a troubled man on the path to redemption. Moreover, the supporting cast is also superb and do the best with the limited material that they are given. Yet, as a whole, even the star-studded cast can't save "Seven Pounds" from being a disaster. Fans of tear-jerking melodramas may enjoy "Seven Pounds" to a certain degree. However, anyone else is best advised to steer clear of this ill-fated car crash of a movie.

Seven Pounds is a character driven drama about a guy aspiring to help seven strangers, finds himself stuck in his past. Such premise that divides itself into various acts often falls apart vigorously and if taken care with such mannerism, it almost questions its existence as it fails to stand on its self-created weak surface. 

This is a typical style over substance case, and unfortunately its style is to take things slowly and reminiscence in its pathos ideology with an artsy camera work to make it look more valuable. The last thing that this feature needed is the first and the foremost things that shucks away its credibility and it is the flawed script that makes less and less sense as it ages, since it skips few steps while mending the sequences. 

The background score is decently scored, the cinematography is daft, the editing is amatuer and the camera work is redundantly busy and handled manually in order to give the personal touch to the viewers. Smith is the only reason to survive this blunder, his looks are impactful and his eyes convey poems but even a performance like such could never save this sinking ship. 

This ill formed structure is equally to be blamed as the premise where the heart may be at the right place but that is never enough to attain a closure out of all these hokum formulas. The narration by Nieporte is unappealing and incongruent to its tone, to a point that even Muccino's execution couldn't save this forsaken and untouched land that this tale resides on. It overcooks its potential substance and overrides the emotions until it grows numb, its fabrication is pointless and inessential to the gist itself.

Seven Pounds costs more than that it accounts for, to the makers, actors and the viewers.

After watching this late at night on Netflix, I was really moved by what I had seen. After watching it, I'm now coming here to write about the film. In all honesty, I'm shocked. I'm surprised at how low the score is and how many people heavily dislike this film. Granted, it wasn't a perfect film in anyway shape or form but I thought it was an emotional piece that kept me invested throughout. It seemed to do what it was made to do and while it has its problems, it certainly has some good things going for it. 

Let's start by saying I think Will Smith is great. This guy can do so much and this is just another emotional performance from him. I've tended to find a lot of attachment to his films like "I Am Legend, "i, Robot", among others, and I think it's because of how strong he excels in his roles. He's someone who can really bring it up to another level and he did great in this film. Him, along with the rest of the cast, did not fail to meet expectations in the slightest. 

Yes, I absolutely understood that the plot was illogical. Maybe this couldn't really happen in real life but regardless, I didn't think it was enough to suspend my belief. This was about a man trying to find the right people to give life to and I think that bodes for a great character study. I feel like I was able to see people's different lives and different perspectives and it really touched me. It wasn't a perfect film but I feel like it did its job. 

One thing I also thought was solid was just the overall tone and feel of the film. Like I said, I really did feel invested in this film. I couldn't completely grasp everything that was going on and the ending, although strong, didn't make much sense. There's some story-telling problems here but I felt like the story-tellers wanted you to think. They told the story and left out a big piece of information but that was the fun part to me.

In the end, "Seven Pounds" provides some emotional moments and some great performances. No, it may not be the perfect film but I think it's certainly worth watching and not nearly as bad as everyone is claiming it to be.

Will Smith, such a charismatic actor, with the ability to totally light up the screen, plays it straight here. What we get is a powerful yet convieniant and unsurprising piece of cinema. Ben Thomas works of the IRS, going through his day to day life by following the sick and debt ridden and either helping them out of a sticky situation or destroying their reputation. Soon he runs into Emily, a gorgeous woman, with a wonderful outlook on life, however she has a fatal heart condition, which at any moment could kill her. It's about here when Ben begins to look after and fall in love with the fate stricken girl, however the deeper down the rabbit hole we go, the more and more we discover that things are not at all as they seem. Seven Pounds is one of THOSE films. It's gripping, it tugs at the heart strings, it really has quite a bit going for it. But for all its hard work, it feels tainted by the inclusion of Smith himself. Not that his performance is bad, quite the opposite, but his star credentials really make it hard to invest and believe in him as a character. The cast is wonderful. Woody Harrellson does a good job with Ezra, a blind pianist who Ben tries to bully into becoming a better man and follow his dreams, Rosario Dawson pulls out an emotional performance as Emily. Will himself, loses weight and really tries to run with the movie. It's just the movies convieniance and layout make for a very predictable finally. The movie flashes back and forth, Letting us know right from the get go that Smith is up to something, that is not spoiling anything as this films opening scene is Smith dialling 911 to report his own suicide. But we also know straight off the bat that his previous life didn't end happily. What would have worked better, would have been to play Smith's past down somewhat, not ignoring it completely but not laying it on so thick either. In fact intrigue is what this film lacks,any intelligent viewer will see 80% of the twists in this film coming very quickly. Also I have an issue with Smith, his performance is a double edged sword, he does a wonderful job, loses the weight, tries not to act the funny man, too much. But had this have been another actor, either less know or better at being a chameleon this film would have packed a harder punch. Dont get me wrong, this film looks wondeful, the sound is brilliant and even the script has beat after beat which keeps the ship afloat. The visuals of the jelly fish also, you will find out after watching, are also brilliant and some comedic moments here and there really help lighten the mood in places. Its a good film, it just could have been better. And the ending... just a little too convieniant for my liking. a powerful and enjoyable watch but had it been handled with more subtley and finesse we would have had something quite remarkable here.

I wasn't sure what to expect from Seven Pounds, but I was told that Will Smith gave a great dramatic performance so I figured I shouldn't miss it.

Seven Pounds is an example of how successful a film can be simply on how many viewers are willing to pay to see someone onscreen. In this case, it's Will Smith because the poster, trailer and name of the film Seven Pounds give no real insight into what the film is really about. It's all a mystery. And Seven Pounds is not a film that I could predict anything out of, because within the intro viewers bear witness to the darker side of Will Smith which is very rarely seen as he is more often a hero of some form or another. But in Seven Pounds the first thing he shows is a relentless aggression and almost passion for chastising a person for being blind. It's an intense emotional sight, and not at all what I expected from Seven Pounds, because while I didn't know what to expect I would never have predicted that America's prince Will Smith would be in the role of a person mocking a blind man. Seven Pounds works as a film which shows off the acting talents of Will Smith you may not have seen before, and that way it does immediately succeed in terms of casting. 
But the mystery of Seven Pounds soon wears thin because the questions viewers ask don't get answered and then the film stops asking questions. It simply descends into being an ambiguously directed melodramatic story which soon turns into a romantic drama that is unpredictable in a no longer good way. It doesn't characterise its protagonist Tim Thomas at all because it tells nothing about him except the slight hint that he has some kind of trouble to him. And while the story deals with some hard hitting dramatic terriroty, it crams it into the film's climax and overloads the dramatic impact after such an extensive period of melodrama which renders it tonally inconsistent. And while the cinematography is nice and the musical score benefits the drama, the drama is really scattershot with the inconsistent pacing and so the whole experience isn't ever as good as it could have been.
Seven Pounds is an ambitious drama at best, and some of its dramatics are powerful. But really it is misguided as a story and doesn't receive enough direction from Gabriele Muccino who fails to live up to the success of his previous collaboration with Will Smith, The Pursuit of Happiness.
Luckily Seven Pounds benefits from a great cast.
Will Smith gives an incredibly powerful lead performance in Seven Pounds. Though the unveiling of the mysterious story in Seven Pounds isn't too effective, his performance is because he ensures that there is constantly a dramatic movement in the story due to his effortful performance in which he displays a true tenacity over the mysterious and grim atmosphere of the story. His facial expressions use a little less tension than many of his other films, and through that minor change to his physicality it is proved that he can change the atmosphere of the story from intensely energetic to depressing through such a simple change, and from there his twice Academy Award nominated dramatic acting skills take over and show off just what he can do. And what he does is give a successful performance which cranks up the effect of Seven Pounds and makes Tim Thomas a character easy to care about or connect to. Will Smith characterises Tim Thomas more than writer Grant Nieporte could, and so he is a genial lead.
Rosario Dawson gives one of the best performances of her career in Seven Pounds, because her supporting performance shows that she shares a superior chemistry with Will Smith to the one they shared in the low quality Men in Black II and she also proves how simply she can construe her true talents as an actress. Her acting talent is largely rooted in her eyes, because where she looks and how she looks at it defines her mood and the height of her emotional subtext in sequences. She has a real power at creating a strong facial expression when the scene calls upon her to do kit, and luckjily her performance never descends into the melodramatic territory that much of the rest of the film ends up doing.
Barry Pepper and Woody Harrelson provide strong presences and good supporting roles key to the story in their own little way as well in Seven Pounds.

So Seven Pounds is a well acted and unpredictable drama, but it doesn't seem any more predictable to the director who fails to give it any sort of consistency whatsoever.

Will Smith is a wonderfully talented actor, but Seven Pounds is wonderfully flawed, presumptuous, and self-congratulatory. From the beginning of the movie, Smith's character plays God as he goes from person to person, judging who is worthy of redemption. We watch this happen again and again, with stereotypical reactions from mostly stereotypical characters. Smith's socially maladapted character (Ben Thomas) fails to create the intrigue that Muccino thinks he does. Muccino attempts to create mystery surrounding Ben Thomas; he actually designs a character with an intense need for psychotherapy and serious interpersonal issues. Muccino spends too much time focusing on Thomas' irritating inability to function as he tries to help others; so much so that by the time we learn why Smith is attempting to save others, our imaginations have created a greater plot than Muccino has directed. The film deserves some credit for attempting uniqueness and artistry, but overall the movie is a macaroni picture brought home by a child from school - the artist thinks the picture is fantastic but the rest of us are saying, "What the heck is that?" Rent it, don't buy it, and balance your checkbook while you watch it.

With Seven Pounds I found that Will Smith can change an adequate movie into a fairly memorable feature. His efforts to put forth a man longing for redemption are recognized, and even the somewhat plainly-delivered plot and slow to build action do not negate so much that it becomes boring. Seven Pounds is a movie of personal sacrifice and spiritual reclamation that tugs on the heart-strings (pun intended) of the audience. The screenplay may not have been the most thrilling, but the premise still remains a strong concept in the modern world. The lesson here presents itself easily to viewers, which might result in too dull a manner for some, but I believe the movie gains merit in its cast and crew. Told a different way, by a different director I might have given this a higher rating, however, while the cast is great, there remain a few story blunders that limit the effect of the movie. I would recommend this movie, due to Smith's appeal and the premise/goal of this movie.
